title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act is titled the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". It includes findings related to financial assistance management. The Congress finds that there are numerous Federal financial assistance programs with duplicative and burdensome administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery. State, local, and tribal governments face complex issues requiring streamlined procedures to improve public service delivery. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, key definitions include the Director as the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Federal agency as any agency defined under title 5, Federal financial assistance as assistance provided to non-Federal entities, local government as a political subdivision of a State, and non-Federal entity as a State, local government, or nonprofit organization. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to any organization operated for public interest, not primarily for profit, and using proceeds to maintain or expand operations. The term "tribal government" refers to an Indian tribe as defined in section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code. The term "uniform administrative rule" refers to a government-wide uniform rule for generally applicable requirements across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to streamline application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, and allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs. The Act requires agencies to streamline application procedures, use a common application system, designate a lead official, allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs, ensure recipients provide high-quality information, and establish annual goals to measure performance. If agencies cannot comply, the Director must report to the Senate and House committees. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for public comment and hold public forums. The lead official must consult with non-Federal entities during plan development and implementation. The Director may extend the plan development period for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months after consulting with Senate and House committees. Each Federal agency must consult with non-Federal entities during the development and implementation of the plan. The agency must submit the plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report may be included in general management reports required by law. The Director is responsible for overseeing the implementation of the plan and reporting annually to Congress on its progress. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes a common application for multiple programs and a common electronic process for managing and reporting funding. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall establish uniform administrative rules and streamline administrative procedures for Federal financial assistance programs across different Federal agencies. This includes improving coordination, information sharing, and timeliness of data pertaining to these programs. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to improve the timeliness, completeness, and quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies must submit information for review regarding their implementation of this Act, and the Director may exempt agencies or programs with few financial assistance programs from the Act's requirements. The Director may exempt agencies with few financial assistance programs from the Act's requirements, maintaining a list of exempted agencies available to the public through OMB's Internet site. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government. The Director will evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government. This includes assessing goals, objectives, and coordination among various entities. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION: The Act allows the Director or any Federal agency to gather necessary information for reviewing the financial integrity of activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW: There is no provision for judicial review of compliance with the Act, and no rights or benefits can be enforced through administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS: The Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET: Specifies the effective date and sunset provisions of the Act. The Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs. It will take effect on the date of enactment and expire five years later.
